metadata.case_name: James Anderson v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Henry Gannon was a resident of British India, assessed to income-tax, left India in 1944 for UK, died on May 13, 1945.
Henry Gannon left a will dated November 18, 1942 appointing National Bank of India Ltd., London as Executor.
Probate of the will granted to the Bank by UK court on October 1, 1945.
Bank gave power of attorney to James Anderson (appellant) on October 25, 1945.
Appellant obtained Letters of Administration with copy of will annexed from Bombay High Court under s.241 Indian Succession Act.
Appellant sold shares and securities of deceased for administration and distribution to legatees; sale price exceeded cost price.
Income Tax Officer treated excess as capital gain under s.12B: assessment year 1947-48 Rs. 20,13,738; 1948-49 Rs. 1,51,963; taxed with dividend and interest.
Appellant appealed to Appellate Tribunal, Bombay; appeals consolidated.
Appellant urged: (1) s.12B ultra vires GOI Act 1935; (2) s.24B limits liability to testator's; (3) sale within third proviso to s.12B(1).
Tribunal repelled first two, accepted third, allowed appeals in part, directed deletion of capital gains.
Commissioner moved Tribunal for reference on third contention; question referred: Whether sale by administrator not a sale under s.12B(1) per third proviso.
At assessee's instance, other two questions also referred to Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No.1 of 1954.
Bombay High Court answered all three questions against assessee on August 25, 1954.
Supreme Court granted special leave on October 7, 1955.

legal_issues.text: True scope and effect of the third proviso to old s.12B(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.12B imposing tax on capital gains ultra vires Government of India Act, 1935.
Under s.24B, appellant liable only for tax testator would have paid; no sale by testator, no liability.
Sale of shares/securities by appellant under will within third proviso to s.12B(1); not treated as sale/transfer of capital assets.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: third proviso to s.12B(1) Income Tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Distribution of capital assets under third proviso means distribution of sale proceeds, not just in specie, to give proviso purpose.
Sale involuntary, by reason of will terms necessitating sale for distribution.

respondent_arguments.text: s.24B does not limit administrator's liability; appellant is assessee liable for capital gains like any individual.
Third proviso applies only to distribution in specie, not sale proceeds; appellant sold assets, not distributed in specie.
Expression 'by reason of' in proviso applies to compulsory acquisition, not distribution under will; voluntariness irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: First two contentions not pressed: ultra vires settled by Navinchandra; s.24B does not limit administrator's liability as assessee.
Scheme of s.12B: sub-s.(1) levies tax on sale/transfer post 31/3/1946 pre 1/4/1948; sub-s.(3) for assets by succession etc., cost to previous owner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax incidence at time of transfer.

court_reasoning.text: Third proviso excludes certain transfers from being 'sale/transfer': includes distribution under will, but means distribution in specie, not sale proceeds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clear distinction between capital assets and sale proceeds.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso serves purpose: protects distribution in specie (no gain to prior owner); sale by administrator or legatee taxable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fits scheme of ss.1,2,3; avoids anomaly where administrator escapes but legatee taxed.

court_reasoning.text: Alternative argument rejected: 'by reason of' links to compulsory acquisition; voluntariness irrelevant to s.12B.

holdings.text: Expression 'distribution of capital assets' in third proviso to s.12B(1) means distribution in specie, not of sale proceeds; appellant's sale taxable.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court, holding that sale of shares/securities by administrator not protected by third proviso to s.12B(1) as it was not distribution in specie but sale preceding distribution of proceeds; capital gains taxable.

key_quotes.text: "the expression distribution of capital assets in the third proviso to sub-s.(1) of s.12B of the Act means distribution in specie and not distribution of sale proceeds."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of proviso

key_quotes.text: "If capital assets are sold first and a distribution of the sale proceeds is made afterwards, then the sale precedes distribution and what is distributed is not capital assets but the sale proceeds thereof."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the purpose is this: as long as there is distribution of the capital assets in specie and no sale, there is no transfer for the purposes of the section but as soon as there is a sale... the liability to tax arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains proviso purpose in scheme of s.12B
